definitions.definition: An out-of-control sliding motion as would result from applying the brakes too hard in a car or other vehicle.
examples: Just before hitting the guardrail the driver was able to regain control and pull out of the skid .

definitions.definition: A shoe or clog, as of iron, attached to a chain, and placed under the wheel of a wagon to prevent its turning when descending a steep hill.
( by extension ) A hook attached to a chain , used for the same purpose.
A piece of timber or other material used as a support, or to receive pressure.

examples: In the hours before daylight he sharpened the skids and tightened the lashings to prepare for the long dogsled journey.

subdefinitions.definition: A ski -shaped runner or supporting surface as found on a helicopter or other aircraft in place of wheels.
examples: Due to frequent arctic travel, the plane was equipped with long skids for snow and ice landings.

subdefinitions.definition: A basic platform for the storage and transport of goods, machinery or equipment, later developed into the pallet .
examples: He unloaded six skids of boxes from the truck.

subdefinitions.definition: One of a pair of horizontal rails or timbers for supporting anything, such as a boat or barrel.

definitions.definition: ( aviation ) A banked sideslip where the aircraft's nose is yawed towards the low wing, often due to excessive rudder input.

main_definition: An out-of-control sliding motion as would result from applying the brakes too hard in a car or other vehicle.
secondary_definitions: A shoe or clog, as of iron, attached to a chain, and placed under the wheel of a wagon to prevent its turning when descending a steep hill.
( by extension ) A hook attached to a chain , used for the same purpose.
A piece of timber or other material used as a support, or to receive pressure.
( aviation ) A banked sideslip where the aircraft's nose is yawed towards the low wing, often due to excessive rudder input.

main_definition: ( UK , slang , obsolete ) A sovereign ( old coin ) .
